awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Interpreting hominin subsistence strategies from small mammal remains
awd_abstract_narration:
A focal issue in archaeological research has been to understand how the emergence of uniquely human attributes (e.g., large brains, complex technologies, and high-fidelity social cooperation) may relate to past changes in dietary and foraging behaviors.  For example, using stone tools to target large-bodied prey and subsequent food-sharing practices most likely formed part of a complex behavioral pattern that satisfied both the caloric and nutritional needs while also building social cohesion and complexity. This doctoral dissertation project will investigate small mammal prey as another potentially important dietary component for hominins. Small mammal acquisition is typically associated with technological complexity (i.e., snares and nets) yet these animals have also been simultaneously considered "easy" targets for early human ancestors that obviate the need for complex tools. Reasons for this contradiction probably lie within the ecological and behavioral diversity of small mammals, which potentially demands a broad range of foraging strategies. The project will advance knowledge about dietary hominin adaptations, foster student training and mentoring, international research collaborations, and public science outreach efforts.

By incorporating taphonomic, ethnoarchaeological, and stable isotope analyses of small mammals remains from a Late Pleistocene and Holocene archaeological sequence, the investigator will test how small mammal subsistence strategies vary between two hominin species (Homo floresiensis and Homo sapiens) and between two modern human subsistence lifestyles (hunting-gathering and agriculture). Taphonomic analyses of small mammal remains will identify which animals were accumulated in the bone assemblage at Liang Bua and what agents (e.g., predators) were responsible. Stable isotope and ethnoarchaeological analyses will be used to elucidate small mammal diet and habitat through time as well as aid in identifying bone surface modifications from modern small mammal hunting practices, respectively. This study will also offer a framework for similar small mammal taphonomic studies investigating subsistence strategies of two hominin species at different geographical time periods and/or regions. In addition, this project will employ a novel Bayesian statistical method for predicting accumulating agents on an assemblage-level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the evolution of the human diet has grossly centered on how accessing fatty nutrients from large-bodied animals affected several biocultural adaptations in the archaeological and fossil record. “Man the Hunter” paradigms from the 1960’s, for example, still influence our perceptions of what ancient hominins (human ancestors and relatives) ate in the past. Thus, smaller animals have largely been ignored from this conversation due to several important biases, including taphonomic, recovery, and preservation, as well as the prevailing assumption that smaller “fast” animals are difficult to catch without the aide of traps, snares, and/or nets – technology associated with modern humans. This project aimed to better understand the role of small mammals as a dietary resource for both a relatively small-brained and small-bodied hominin (Homo floresiensis) and modern humans (Homo sapiens), as well as between two subsistence pathways (i.e., foraging vs agriculturalism) at Liang Bua – an archaeological cave site located on the Indonesian island of Flores.

A zooarchaeological and taphonomic assessment was performed on ~8,000 skeletal elements identified as murines (i.e., rats), which comprise roughly 78% of the total faunal assemblage at Liang Bua. Nine endemic rats were identified in the Liang Bua faunal assemblage, and these murines range in body size from small (50 g) to giant (3.5 kg) as well as habitat and dietary preferences. For example, carbon stable isotope analyses indicate that Komodomys rintjanus, a medium-sized rat, is a dietary specialist consuming primarily grasses, while all other taxa tend to have more flexible diets. Thus, the goals of this study were to identify (1) the predator responsible for accumulating the large assemblage of rat bones, and (2) where these predators were hunting these rats on the landscape around Liang Bua. Since there are no endemic mammalian predators on the island, the only possible predators capable of accumulating a large assemblage of rat bones were either raptors (i.e., predatory birds) or humans.

Results indicate that both Homo floresiensis (from ~190 – 50 ka), foraging modern humans (~46 – 3 ka), and agriculturalists (< ~3 ka) consumed rats at Liang Bua. There is variation in the size of rat that was consumed as well as exploitation of different ecologies, but overall, rats seem to be a consistent dietary resource for hominins at Liang Bua. Even so, with the case of Homo floresiensis, in the presence of Stegodon (a small proboscidean) rats were still being consumed. For example, butchery patterns indicate that Homo floresiensis was consuming primarily medium and giant-sized open habitat adapted rats while modern humans were consuming rats of all body sizes and ecologies. Also, there is an increase in the number and kinds of rats that were being consumed prior to agricultural practices suggesting either a shift towards a sedentary lifestyle or an increase in population sizes around Liang Bua. Another major finding is that Homo floresiensis was not using fire, unlike modern humans.

As the first study to compare the diets and foraging behaviors between two human species in Southeast Asia, this project revealed several important assumptions held in paleoanthropology as well as paleoecological insights at Liang Bua. First, small-brained and small-bodied hominins were capable of capturing small “fast” prey as a dietary resource. Second, that more-open grassland and shrubland habitats not only provided hominins with sources of large-bodied animals (e.g., Stegodon), but also ample amounts of smaller animals to hunt. Third, smaller animals likely played a larger dietary role in human evolution than had been previously assumed (depending on temporal, ecological, and geographic contexts). Overall, this study revealed that rodents of unusual size were a reliable dietary resource for Homo floresiensis and modern humans at Liang Bua, Flores, Indonesia.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2022
Modified by: Elizabeth G Veatch
